course.subject: ISOM
course.name: Introduction to Business Analytics
course.description: This course introduces students with the foundation needed to apply data analytics to real-world challenges they will confront in their future career. It covers statistical tools in descriptive analytics and predictive analytics, including multiple linear regression, logistic regression and clustering. Emphasis is placed on applications, concepts and interpretation of results, rather than theory and calculations. Students use a computer software for data analysis. For SBM and DDP students only.

reviews.title: Poorly designed syllabus
reviews.comment_content:
1.Introduction to multiple regression
2.Transformation and interaction of variables
3.Regression model selection
4.Classification and supervised learning
5.Clustering and unsupervised learning

For a course with a length of six weeks and only one lecture per week, the content is overwhelming. Not only the concepts themselves are difficult to interpret, but also the instructor struggles to explain them bit by bit due to the tight schedule. Also, the content requires some basic knowledge on linear regression learnt in ISOM 2500 in the previous semester, which I believe that majority of the students in my class have forgotten all of them. The lab session on the other hand is simply about python, teaching us how to do the codings for the content covered in lectures. All in all this course is like a combination of ISOM 2020 and ISOM 2500, but with more difficult content.

reviews.author: Mivy Wenceslas
reviews.title: Let me Clarify ISOM2600
reviews.comment_content:
Topic 1:  Multiple Linear Regression Model
Topic 2:  Model/Variable Selection
Topic 3:  Classification Analysis
Topic 4:  Clustering Analysis

A lot of people say that the syllabus of this course is useless. This is utterly wrong. These are all very practical content for any kind of data science and analysis.

The only issue is that there are only 5 weeks to teach, so they only talk about the basics. As a result, people may get confused to what they actually are without prior knowledge.

I would recommend you to search online to gain more insights instead, but as an introduction course it serves its purpose.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I saw that a lot of posts claimed that Professor Wan has terrible handwriting and horrible delivery. This is partially true.

Indeed, his handwriting is quite bad and his delivery throughout is not very fluent, but understandable. More importantly, to compensate this, he gives out a lot more examples in the teachings.

Moreover, his notes are actually on point and relevant if you extract carefully. He is also the rare type of professor who provides final review and past paper exercises for you to do, which is extremely practical. He is also willing to answer any questions.

I would say he is a professor that prefer writing than saying, and he is definitely passionate in the teachings. If you have any questions, then ask him or search Google first. I do not think he is in any way bad given his notes quality and teachings.

He also cut the syllabus on point to save time, given that he spent a lot of time in Topic 0, which is just introduction.

For the Lab Session, I got Yvonne Chan. Her job is to basically talk about the code and give you an understanding of it.

Now, I do not know who write the code, but there are simpler expressions obviously and the most relevant code such as feature selection is hidden in another file. So, it is not easy to teach these code especially when people don't know much of Python. However, Chan has tried her best to invigorate your interest and answered any questions as well as give you more understanding about the code. I think she has done her job.
reviews.comment_grading:
While people are complaining, this is a very competitive course. One mark in the final exam could easily affect one subgrade.

10% Attendance
40% Assignment
50% Final Exam

I believe to get an A+, you have to get around 99%-100% overall. If you get around mean in Final Exam, you easily get B at most. Basically, a very competitive course where every mark matters.
reviews.comment_workload:

There are 2 coding assignments, but you can form a team on your own. You can also copy the code from the Lab, so not difficult. A lot of time is given anyways.

Overall, low workload.

I would also like to note that this course is largely irrelevant to ISOM2020, not sure how they are corequisite. In this course, you do not need Python in the final exam, only the assignments. In the assignment, they actually use a lot more advanced knowledge than in ISOM2020. Libraries such as Pandas and Matplotlib is used. There is also list comprehension. These are not taught in ISOM2020 at all, so I think it is better to just copy the code in the Lab.

reviews.author: professorwok
reviews.title: Unsure about the positioning of this course...
reviews.comment_content:
As Kris said; it is neither a python course nor a statistic course, but a business analytics course. In reality, you are tested on the outputs and mistakes within the python code, and interpreting the statistics from the computer-generated results. You learn nothing about the theory behind the techniques...

As an extension of ISOM 2500 and ISOM 2020, it is assumed you fully understand the contents of those courses before entering.

To be honest, I basically learnt nothing as the content is so shallow.

Topic 0. Introduction to the course
Topic 1. List, Arrays, Graphing (with numpy, scipy, matplotlib libraries)
Topic 2. Pandas (pandas library)
Topic 3. Recap Single Linear Regression and Multiple Linear Regression (scikit-learn and other libraries)
Topic 4. Clustering (k-means method only)

Topic 4 is considerably shorter than previous years as many lectures were missed (Due to holiday and fire drills).
reviews.comment_teaching:
Kris is a nice person who responds to all your questions patiently. Also, she gives a lot of breaks to do practise questions. However, like with ISOM 2020 and ISOM 2600, the teaching is terrible. She just read directly from the ppt very quickly and does not explain much things in detail, especially the concepts. You are just assumed to memorize everything.

The TAs are utterly hopeless... In the lab, the TA goes through the code super quickly with no explanation. they also don't seem to reply many emails, and the assignments have so many typos that they have to reupload them multiple times over the span of a week.

There is barely any past paper questions, and the questions are so easy that I feel its better to just search up similar topics online and practise off those.
reviews.comment_grading:
Lenient cutoff as the exam is harder than previous years. A-range seems to be big as well.

10% Attendance (Count 5/6 lectures)
30% Two Group Assignments (on ipynb)
60% Final Exam (1 hour, 30 MC questions)

The group assignments are super easy and most get full marks.

In the final, you are allowed 2 two-sided A4 cheat sheets. NOTE: LAB CONTENT is tested
The exam was significantly harder this year, and I think some of the questions are not even taught in the lectures (but they may be small print in the lab or ppt). Also, be sure to revise the appendix and other 'optional' contents; they are also tested.

Exam stats (/30): Mean 20.9, SD 4.1

Me: Attendance 6/5, Assignments full, Final 26/30. Finally get A.
My friend: 25/30 and also finally get A
reviews.comment_workload:
As a 1-credit half-semester course, you are expected to attend 2 hours of lecture and 1 hours of lab per week. I would say the workload is lower than ISOM 2020 but it still feels like a 1.5-2 credit course.

The assignments are easy if you work in a group. You can just copy the code based on the samples provided in the ipynb file or the powerpoint. Be sure to triple check your answers because everyone gets full marks.

The final questions are relatively easy for the most part. Be careful as many of the questions have 2 obvious answers; its a 50/50 gamble most of the time. Also, ensure to copy everything into your cheat sheets, as you are tested on syntax and output as well.

NOTE: Some questions test on combining multiple methods from DIFFERENT LIBRARIES: ITS NOT TAUGHT IN THE PPT OR LAB.

    - 45% from topic 3 & 4

To answer the majority of the final exam questions, you really need to understand what is going on for each topic - a reason why the content might be overwhelming.

Personally, I prepared by extracting key points in the handouts to the cheatsheets and looked at some tricky topics on YouTube. The recordings are not especially useful. Do pay attention to how some functions behave as well.

If you have some data science background and played around with the trio of pandas, matplotlib, and numpy before, this course should be much easier. You can even finish the group assignments individually - most of the codes can be copied from tutorials anyways.

Even lighter workload if you have a friend who can give you the access code to the Canvas quiz, i.e skipping the lecture.

However, the downsides of this course is that the content was too much for a one credit course, and it should be extended to a full semester duration instead of only half. Since there are only 6 lessons, the professor and TA(in lab) are always in a hurry, they just have time to introduce the terms, explain what it does and then rush through it, no mathematical derivation/proof, and no intuition explained.
reviews.comment_teaching: Very good. Professor Pan’s accent is not native but comfortable, she explains clearly and patiently answer the questions raised by students. She even made a Cantonese Q&A session where she spend hours on using Cantonese to teach again and answer questions. But again, it is not easy to follow her pace in lessons since the course schedule was tight and therefore she taught really quickly, I think it was not her problem tho.

reviews.comment_workload:
The worst part of this course. If the workload in ISOM2020 is 1.5 credit, this course is ~3.5 credits, even the workload of 2020 is so light compare to this course.

Personally, I spent ~2hrs on lecture, additional 2-3hrs on revising the lecture, take notes and replaying the lecture video, and then ~1.5hr on learning the lab code, finally ~3hrs on the assignment each week! The assignments are difficult, they require you to be able to follow the labs to code, and then use your lecture concepts to explain/ interpret. What our group do was each do the hw once all by ourselves and cross-check. It was painful but it’s the only way that we get most out of this course.

To make this course better, they should increase the credit to 3 and make it last for the whole semester!
